id: bigtech:a cup of coffee for depression treatment has better results :2026-01-31T12:19:01.000Z
title: A cup of coffee for depression treatment has better results than microdosing
author: John Semley, wired.com
summary_long: About a decade ago, many media outlets—including WIRED—zeroed in on a weird trend at the intersection of mental health, drug science, and Silicon Valley biohacking: microdosing, or the practice of taking a small amount of a psychedelic drug seeking not full-blown hallucinatory revels but gentler, more stable effects. Typically using psilocybin mushrooms or LSD, the archetypal microdoser sought less melting walls and open-eye kaleidoscopic visuals than boosts in mood and energy, like a gentle spring breeze blowing through the mind. Anecdotal reports pitched microdosing as a kind of psychedelic Swiss Army knife, providing everything from increased focus to a spiked libido and (perhaps most promisingly) lowered reported levels of depression. It was a miracle for many. Source: arstechnica.com. Date: 2026-01-31. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: consumer:ayaneos pocket s mini has the perfect aspect ratio for revis:2026-01-31T20:39:28.000Z
title: Ayaneo's Pocket S Mini has the perfect aspect ratio for revisiting classic console games
author: Jackson Chen
summary_long: There may be plenty of gaming handhelds out there, but there aren't many horizontal options that let you play childhood favorites in the original 4:3 aspect ratio. To address that gap, Ayaneo launched a premium option with the Pocket S Mini. As a "true 4:3 retro handheld," the Pocket S Mini won't have those pesky vertical black bars whenever you're emulating video games from the CRT television era. Handhelds like the Anbernic RG405M and even Ayaneo's own Pocket Air Mini already offer a 4:3 aspect ratio, but the Pocket S Mini presents a more high-end build with a full metal frame and a glass front panel. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2026-01-31. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: nextfrontiers:geometry behind how ai agents learn revealed:2026-01-31T18:40:02.000Z
title: Geometry behind how AI agents learn revealed
summary_long: A new study from the University at Albany shows that artificial intelligence systems may organize information in far more intricate ways than previously thought. The study, "Exploring the Stratified Space Structure of an RL Game with the Volume Growth Transform," has been published online through arXiv. Source: techxplore.com. Date: 2026-01-31. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: consumer:spacex wants to launch a constellation of a million satellit:2026-01-31T17:56:07.000Z
title: SpaceX wants to launch a constellation of a million satellites to power AI needs
author: Jackson Chen
summary_long: Elon Musk and his aerospace company have requested to build a network that's 100 times the number of satellites that are currently in orbit. On Friday, SpaceX filed an application with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to launch a million satellites meant to create an "orbital data center." This isn't the first time we're hearing of Musk's plans to build an orbital data center, as it was mentioned by company insiders following the news that the CEO was reportedly preparing to take SpaceX public. According to the filing spotted by PCMag, this data center would run off solar power and deliver computing capacity for artificial intelligence needs. SpaceX is requesting to "deploy a system of up to one million satellites to operate within narrow orbital shells spanning up to 50 km each," as detailed in the filing. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2026-01-31. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society.

id: consumer:blue origin is pausing its space tourist flights to work on :2026-01-31T14:30:00.000Z
title: Blue Origin is pausing its space tourist flights to work on lunar landers for NASA
author: Mariella Moon
summary_long: Blue Origin plans to put a focus on the development of its human lunar capabilities, so it won’t be sending tourists to space for at least the next two years. That means we won’t be seeing any New Shepard launches for quite some time. Blue Origin is one of the companies NASA chose to develop human landing systems for its Artemis program, along with SpaceX. Specifically, it will work on landers for the Artemis III and Artemis V missions. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2026-01-31. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: nextfrontiers:taking the heat out of industrial chemical separations:2026-01-31T18:30:01.000Z
title: Taking the heat out of industrial chemical separations
summary_long: The modern world runs on chemicals and fuels that require a huge amount of energy to produce: Industrial chemical separation accounts for 10% to 15% of the world's total energy consumption. That's because most separations today rely on heat to boil off unwanted materials and isolate compounds. Source: techxplore.com. Date: 2026-01-31.
